hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input. You have two sentences represented as lists of words and a list of pairs that indicate which words are similar. Make sure to clearly differentiate between the words in the sentences and the similarity pairs.
Consider how to represent the relationships between words. A good approach would be to use a graph where each word is a node and each similarity pair represents an undirected edge between two nodes.
Think about how you can traverse this graph. A depth-first search (DFS) or breadth-first search (BFS) could be useful to find if two words are connected through the similarity pairs.
When checking if two sentences are similar, remember that the sentences must have the same length. If they don't, you can immediately return false.
For each pair of words from the two sentences, check if they are directly equal or if they can be connected through the graph you created. This will require checking both words in the pair.
Consider edge cases where the similarity pairs might not connect all words. For example, if one word has no connections at all, how would that affect your comparison?
You may want to implement a helper function that checks if two words are similar by exploring their connections in the graph. This function can utilize DFS or BFS to explore all reachable nodes.
Don't forget to handle cases where the similarity pairs are empty. If there are no pairs, the only way two words can be considered similar is if they are identical.
As you implement your solution, make sure to keep track of visited nodes to avoid infinite loops during your graph traversal. This is especially important in cases where there are cycles.

Finally, piece everything together. Loop through the words in both sentences, using your similarity check function to determine if they are similar. Return true if all pairs are similar, otherwise return false.

questionNotes: Both sentences must be of the same length to be considered similar.
The similarity pairs are undirected; if 'a' is similar to 'b', then 'b' is similar to 'a'.
Handle cases where there are no similarity pairs; only identical words should be considered similar.
Consider using a graph representation for the words and their similarities.
